2024792.description: A device on your network may be infected with Emotet, a dangerous banking trojan that steals credentials and spreads to other computers.
2024792.risk_context: Emotet is one of the most destructive malware families. It can steal passwords, banking credentials, and install additional malware like ransomware.
2024792.recommendation: Immediately isolate the affected device from your network. Run a full antivirus scan. Change all passwords that were used on this device.

2025391.description: A device may be infected with Trickbot, a banking trojan that targets financial credentials and can deploy ransomware.
2025391.risk_context: Trickbot is often used as a precursor to ransomware attacks (Ryuk, Conti). It spreads laterally across networks.
2025391.recommendation: Isolate the affected device immediately. Scan all network devices. Check for unauthorized file changes and credential theft.

2027865.signature: ET MALWARE Cobalt Strike Beacon Activity
2027865.description: A device appears to be communicating with a Cobalt Strike command-and-control server, indicating a sophisticated targeted attack.
2027865.risk_context: Cobalt Strike is a commercial penetration testing tool frequently abused by threat actors for advanced persistent threat (APT) operations.
2027865.recommendation: This is a critical incident. Isolate the device, engage your incident response team, and preserve forensic evidence.

2024897.description: A device may be infected with QBot (Qakbot), a banking trojan that steals financial data and email conversations.
2024897.risk_context: QBot can hijack email threads to spread to contacts, steal banking credentials, and deploy ransomware.
2024897.recommendation: Isolate the device. Check for suspicious emails sent from the user's account. Change all financial and email passwords.

2014726.signature: ET TROJAN DNS Query for Known Ransomware Domain
2014726.description: A device looked up a domain associated with ransomware activity, which may indicate an infection attempting to communicate with its operators.
2014726.risk_context: Ransomware can encrypt all files on a device and across network shares, demanding payment for recovery.
2014726.recommendation: Immediately isolate the device. Check for encrypted files. Ensure backups are intact and not connected to the network.

2016150.signature: ET INFO Observed DNS Query to .onion TLD
2016150.description: A device attempted to resolve a Tor hidden service (.onion) address through regular DNS, which may indicate Tor usage or malware communication.
2016150.risk_context: While Tor has legitimate uses, malware frequently uses .onion addresses for command-and-control to evade detection.
2016150.recommendation: Investigate the device to determine if Tor usage is authorized. Check for malware if Tor access is unexpected.

2013028.description: A device is making HTTP requests using the curl command-line tool, which could indicate automated scripts or tools running.
2013028.risk_context: While curl is a common tool, automated curl requests from unexpected devices may indicate scripted data exfiltration or C2 communication.
2013028.recommendation: Verify that curl usage from this device is expected and authorized. Check for unknown cron jobs or scripts.

2010935.signature: ET SCAN Nmap Scripting Engine User-Agent Detected
2010935.description: Network scanning tool Nmap was detected actively scanning your network, which could be unauthorized reconnaissance.
2010935.risk_context: Nmap scanning often precedes attacks. An attacker maps open ports and services before exploiting vulnerabilities.
2010935.recommendation: Identify the source device. If scanning is unauthorized, investigate for compromise. Block the scanning source if external.

2002910.description: Multiple SSH connection attempts were detected, suggesting someone is scanning for open SSH ports or attempting to brute-force credentials.
2002910.risk_context: SSH brute-force attacks try common usernames and passwords. A successful attack gives full remote access to the compromised system.
2002910.recommendation: Ensure SSH uses key-based authentication. Consider fail2ban or similar rate limiting. Block the scanning IP if external.

2002911.description: Multiple VNC connection attempts were detected, suggesting someone is scanning for open remote desktop ports.
2002911.risk_context: VNC provides graphical remote access. Unsecured VNC servers are a common entry point for attackers.
2002911.recommendation: Ensure VNC is password-protected and not exposed to the internet. Consider using a VPN for remote access instead.

2010937.signature: ET SCAN Suspicious inbound to MSSQL port 1433
2010937.description: Inbound connections to the Microsoft SQL Server port were detected, which may indicate database scanning or attack attempts.
2010937.risk_context: Database servers exposed to the internet are prime targets. SQL injection and brute-force attacks can lead to data breaches.
2010937.recommendation: Ensure MSSQL is not exposed to the internet. Use strong authentication and keep the server updated.

2010936.signature: ET SCAN Suspicious inbound to MySQL port 3306
2010936.description: Inbound connections to the MySQL database port were detected, suggesting database scanning or unauthorized access attempts.
2010936.risk_context: Exposed MySQL servers are frequently targeted for data theft. Attackers may attempt SQL injection or credential brute-force.
2010936.recommendation: Ensure MySQL is bound to localhost or behind a firewall. Use strong passwords and limit remote access.

2100498.signature: GPL ATTACK_RESPONSE id check returned root
2100498.description: A system returned a response indicating root-level access, suggesting a successful privilege escalation attack.
2100498.risk_context: Root access means complete control over a system. An attacker with root can install backdoors, steal data, and pivot to other systems.
2100498.recommendation: This is critical. Immediately isolate the system, investigate the attack vector, and rebuild the system from known-good backups.

2019284.signature: ET EXPLOIT Possible Apache Struts OGNL Injection
2019284.description: An attempt to exploit an Apache Struts vulnerability was detected. This can allow remote code execution on the web server.
2019284.risk_context: Apache Struts vulnerabilities (like the one behind the Equifax breach) allow attackers to execute arbitrary commands on the server.
2019284.recommendation: Immediately update Apache Struts to the latest version. Review web server logs for signs of successful exploitation.

2024364.signature: ET EXPLOIT Apache Log4j RCE Attempt
2024364.description: An attempt to exploit the Log4Shell (Log4j) vulnerability was detected. This critical vulnerability allows remote code execution.
2024364.risk_context: Log4Shell (CVE-2021-44228) is one of the most critical vulnerabilities discovered. It allows complete system takeover.
2024364.recommendation: Update all Java applications using Log4j immediately. Check for signs of exploitation in server logs.

2034700.signature: ET EXPLOIT Possible Spring4Shell Exploit Attempt
2034700.description: An attempt to exploit the Spring4Shell vulnerability in Spring Framework was detected, potentially allowing remote code execution.
2034700.risk_context: Spring4Shell allows attackers to achieve remote code execution on Spring Framework applications under certain conditions.
2034700.recommendation: Update Spring Framework to patched versions. Review application logs for exploitation indicators.

2027369.signature: ET EXPLOIT Possible Microsoft Exchange ProxyShell Exploit
2027369.description: An attempt to exploit Microsoft Exchange ProxyShell vulnerabilities was detected, which can lead to remote code execution.
2027369.risk_context: ProxyShell allows unauthenticated attackers to execute arbitrary commands on Exchange servers, often leading to web shells or ransomware.
2027369.recommendation: Apply all Exchange security updates immediately. Check for web shells or unauthorized mailbox access.

2014169.signature: ET DNS Non-DNS or Non-Compliant DNS traffic on DNS port
2014169.description: Non-standard traffic was detected on the DNS port (53). This may indicate DNS tunneling used for data exfiltration or C2 communication.
2014169.risk_context: DNS tunneling encodes data within DNS queries to bypass firewalls. It is commonly used by malware to exfiltrate data covertly.
2014169.recommendation: Inspect the DNS traffic for unusual patterns (long subdomains, high query volume). Consider DNS filtering or monitoring tools.

2025012.signature: ET DNS Query for Suspicious Newly Observed Domain
2025012.description: A device queried a recently registered domain. Newly created domains are frequently used in phishing and malware campaigns.
2025012.risk_context: Attackers often register new domains for short-lived campaigns. Legitimate services rarely use brand-new domains.
2025012.recommendation: Investigate why this domain was accessed. Check if any user received a phishing email. Block the domain if suspicious.

2027863.signature: ET DNS Query to a *.top domain
2027863.description: A device queried a .top domain. This TLD has a high rate of abuse in phishing and malware campaigns.
2027863.risk_context: The .top TLD is inexpensive and popular among malicious actors for throwaway domains used in scams and malware distribution.
2027863.recommendation: Review the specific domain. If it's not a known legitimate service, investigate the device that made the query.

2013504.signature: ET POLICY GNU/Linux APT User-Agent Outbound
2013504.description: A Linux device is performing package manager updates. This is typically normal system maintenance activity.
2013504.risk_context: APT package manager traffic is normal for Linux systems. However, unexpected apt activity may indicate unauthorized software installation.
2013504.recommendation: Verify this is an authorized Linux system performing routine updates. No action needed if expected.

2016338.description: A Dropbox client was detected broadcasting on the local network for LAN sync. This is normal Dropbox behavior.
2016338.risk_context: Dropbox LAN sync allows faster file sharing between local computers. It may expose file-sharing activity to network monitoring.
2016338.recommendation: Verify Dropbox usage is authorized on your network. Consider if cloud storage use aligns with your data policies.

2013505.description: A device is making HTTP requests using Python's urllib library, indicating automated scripts or applications.
2013505.risk_context: While Python scripts are common, unexpected urllib traffic may indicate automated data collection or malicious scripts.
2013505.recommendation: Identify the source application. Verify the Python scripts running on this device are authorized.

2019714.signature: ET POLICY External IP Lookup via api.ipify.org
2019714.description: A device is checking its external IP address via ipify.org. Malware frequently checks external IPs to determine network location.
2019714.risk_context: While checking external IPs is not inherently malicious, malware uses this technique to fingerprint the network before reporting to C2.
2019714.recommendation: Determine which application is performing the lookup. If unexpected, investigate the device for malware.

2023756.description: A device may be infected with IcedID (BokBot), a banking trojan that targets financial institutions and steals credentials.
2023756.risk_context: IcedID uses web injection attacks to steal banking credentials and can deploy additional malware including ransomware.
2023756.recommendation: Isolate the affected device. Change all banking credentials. Monitor financial accounts for unauthorized transactions.

2019232.description: A device may be infected with Dridex, a banking trojan known for stealing financial credentials and distributing ransomware.
2019232.risk_context: Dridex targets online banking and can deploy BitPaymer or DoppelPaymer ransomware on enterprise networks.
2019232.recommendation: Isolate the device. Check for unusual financial transactions. Scan all network endpoints for Dridex indicators.

2025019.signature: ET MALWARE Possible Raccoon Stealer Activity
2025019.description: A device may be infected with Raccoon Stealer, malware that harvests passwords, browser cookies, and cryptocurrency wallets.
2025019.risk_context: Raccoon Stealer targets saved browser credentials, autofill data, and cryptocurrency wallets across multiple applications.
2025019.recommendation: Isolate the device. Change all passwords stored in browsers. Check cryptocurrency wallets for unauthorized access.

2027371.signature: ET MALWARE Possible AsyncRAT C2 Communication
2027371.description: A device appears to be communicating with an AsyncRAT command-and-control server, giving an attacker remote access.
2027371.risk_context: AsyncRAT provides attackers with keylogging, screen capture, credential theft, and full remote control capabilities.
2027371.recommendation: Immediately isolate the device. Check for keylogger artifacts. Change all credentials used on this device.

2028401.description: A device may be infected with Agent Tesla, a spyware that captures keystrokes, screenshots, and credentials.
2028401.risk_context: Agent Tesla is a popular information stealer sold on underground forums. It captures everything typed and can access saved credentials.
2028401.recommendation: Isolate the device. Change all credentials. Check email for phishing messages that may have delivered the malware.

2031711.signature: ET MALWARE Possible RedLine Stealer Activity
2031711.description: A device may be infected with RedLine Stealer, malware that extracts passwords, cookies, and cryptocurrency data from browsers.
2031711.risk_context: RedLine is one of the most prevalent info-stealers. It targets browser data, FTP credentials, and cryptocurrency wallets.
2031711.recommendation: Isolate the device. Change all browser-saved passwords. Enable 2FA on all critical accounts.

2014411.signature: ET TROJAN Possible Zeus GameOver Activity
2014411.description: A device may be part of the Zeus GameOver botnet, one of the most sophisticated banking trojans ever created.
2014411.risk_context: Zeus GameOver uses peer-to-peer communication to resist takedown and can steal banking credentials with high effectiveness.
2014411.recommendation: Isolate the device. Contact your bank about potential credential compromise. Run comprehensive malware removal tools.

2018959.description: A device may be infected with CryptoLocker ransomware, which encrypts personal files and demands payment for decryption.
2018959.risk_context: CryptoLocker encrypts documents, photos, and other files using strong encryption. Without backups, file recovery may be impossible.
2018959.recommendation: Immediately disconnect the device. Do NOT pay the ransom. Check backup integrity. Consult a cybersecurity professional.

2024218.signature: ET TROJAN Observed Possible WannaCry Ransomware Activity
2024218.description: Activity consistent with WannaCry ransomware was detected. WannaCry can spread automatically across networks via SMB.
2024218.risk_context: WannaCry exploits the EternalBlue vulnerability to spread without user interaction. It can encrypt an entire network in minutes.
2024218.recommendation: Apply MS17-010 patch immediately. Block SMB ports at the firewall. Isolate affected devices and check all endpoints.

2016149.signature: ET INFO Possible Bitcoin Mining Activity
2016149.description: A device may be performing cryptocurrency mining, which consumes significant CPU/GPU resources and electricity.
2016149.risk_context: Unauthorized crypto mining (cryptojacking) wastes resources, increases electricity costs, and shortens hardware lifespan.
2016149.recommendation: Identify the mining process. If unauthorized, check for cryptojacking malware. Block mining pool connections at the firewall.

2023882.signature: ET INFO Observed Cryptocurrency Mining Stratum Protocol
2023882.description: Cryptocurrency mining protocol traffic was detected, indicating a device is actively mining cryptocurrency.
2023882.risk_context: Stratum protocol is used by mining software to communicate with mining pools. This consumes resources and bandwidth.
2023882.recommendation: Investigate whether mining is authorized. If not, scan the device for mining malware and block mining pool addresses.

2024449.description: High-speed network scanning from the Masscan tool was detected. Masscan can scan the entire internet in under 6 minutes.
2024449.risk_context: Masscan is extremely aggressive. When used without authorization, it indicates serious reconnaissance for attack planning.
2024449.recommendation: Identify the source immediately. If external, block the IP. If internal, investigate the device for compromise.

2009358.description: An Nmap SYN scan was detected, a common technique to discover open ports on network devices.
2009358.risk_context: SYN scanning is a stealthy technique that doesn't complete TCP handshakes. It's the most popular scanning method for attackers.
2009358.recommendation: Identify the scanning source. Verify if this is an authorized security assessment. Block unauthorized scanners.

2010934.description: An Nmap stealth SYN scan with a specific TCP window size was detected, a technique used to fingerprint network services.
2010934.risk_context: This specific Nmap signature indicates a deliberate attempt to discover services while minimizing detection.
2010934.recommendation: Investigate the scanner. If unauthorized, block the source and review affected hosts for vulnerabilities.

2100366.description: An ICMP information reply was detected. While often benign, this can be used for network reconnaissance.
2100366.risk_context: ICMP information requests are legacy protocols sometimes used to map network topology.
2100366.recommendation: Consider filtering unnecessary ICMP types at your firewall. No immediate action typically required.

2100368.description: An ICMP timestamp reply was detected. This can reveal system uptime and clock skew information.
2100368.risk_context: ICMP timestamp replies can reveal when systems were last rebooted and help fingerprint operating systems.
2100368.recommendation: Consider blocking ICMP timestamp requests at the firewall if not needed for legitimate purposes.

2101411.description: A device is responding to SNMP queries with the default 'public' community string, exposing system information.
2101411.risk_context: Default SNMP community strings allow anyone to read device configuration, network details, and system information.
2101411.recommendation: Change SNMP community strings from defaults. Restrict SNMP access to authorized management stations only.

2027757.signature: ET WEB_SERVER SQL Injection Attack Detected
2027757.description: An SQL injection attack was detected against a web server on your network, attempting to manipulate database queries.
2027757.risk_context: SQL injection can allow attackers to read, modify, or delete database content, potentially accessing all user data.
2027757.recommendation: Review web application code for SQL injection vulnerabilities. Use parameterized queries. Apply a web application firewall.

2027758.description: A cross-site scripting (XSS) attack was detected against a web server, attempting to inject malicious scripts.
2027758.risk_context: XSS attacks can steal user session cookies, redirect users to malicious sites, or deface web applications.
2027758.recommendation: Implement input validation and output encoding. Use Content Security Policy (CSP) headers. Update web frameworks.

2027759.description: A directory traversal attack was detected, attempting to access files outside the web server's intended directory.
2027759.risk_context: Successful directory traversal can expose configuration files, credentials, or system files to attackers.
2027759.recommendation: Validate and sanitize file paths in web applications. Apply web server configuration hardening.

2013926.signature: ET WEB_CLIENT Java Class Download Attempt
2013926.description: A device attempted to download a Java class file, which could be a drive-by download exploit attempt.
2013926.risk_context: Malicious Java applets have historically been used to exploit browser vulnerabilities and install malware.
2013926.recommendation: Disable Java browser plugins if not needed. Keep Java updated. Investigate the source URL for malicious content.

2016141.signature: ET WEB_CLIENT Suspicious PDF Download with Embedded JavaScript
2016141.description: A PDF file containing embedded JavaScript was downloaded, which could contain exploit code.
2016141.risk_context: Malicious PDFs can exploit vulnerabilities in PDF readers to install malware when opened.
2016141.recommendation: Scan the downloaded PDF with antivirus. Update PDF reader software. Warn users about suspicious PDF attachments.

2024291.signature: ET HUNTING Possible Phishing Domain Observed
2024291.description: A device accessed a domain that resembles a known brand, potentially a phishing site designed to steal credentials.
2024291.risk_context: Phishing domains mimic legitimate websites to trick users into entering passwords, credit card numbers, or personal information.
2024291.recommendation: Warn the user. Check if any credentials were entered on the suspicious site. Change passwords for any compromised accounts.

2027300.signature: ET HUNTING External IP Lookup via ip-api.com
2027300.description: A device checked its external IP and geolocation via ip-api.com. This is sometimes done by malware to fingerprint the network.
2027300.risk_context: While IP lookups can be benign, malware uses geolocation to determine if it should activate based on the victim's location.
2027300.recommendation: Identify the application making the request. If unexpected, investigate the device for potential malware.

2024320.signature: ET DOS Possible NTP DDoS Amplification Attack
2024320.description: An NTP amplification attack pattern was detected, where NTP servers are abused to flood a target with traffic.
2024320.risk_context: NTP amplification can multiply attack traffic by 500x, overwhelming the target's bandwidth and causing service outages.
2024320.recommendation: Configure NTP servers to disable monlist. Rate-limit NTP responses. Block suspicious NTP traffic at the firewall.

2024322.signature: ET DOS Possible DNS Amplification Attack
2024322.description: A DNS amplification attack pattern was detected, where open DNS resolvers are abused to flood a target.
2024322.risk_context: DNS amplification can multiply attack traffic by 50-70x, causing severe bandwidth exhaustion at the target.
2024322.recommendation: Ensure your DNS servers are not open resolvers. Implement response rate limiting (RRL) on DNS servers.

2023549.signature: ET DROP Spamhaus DROP Listed Traffic Inbound
2023549.description: Traffic from an IP on the Spamhaus DROP (Don't Route Or Peer) list was detected. This IP is known to be malicious.
2023549.risk_context: The Spamhaus DROP list contains IP ranges allocated to known cybercriminals. All traffic from these IPs is considered hostile.
2023549.recommendation: Block all traffic from this IP range at the firewall. Investigate any internal devices that communicated with this source.

2400000.signature: ET DROP Dshield Block Listed Source
2400000.description: Traffic from an IP on the DShield block list was detected. This IP has been reported for malicious activity.
2400000.risk_context: DShield aggregates firewall logs from around the world. Listed IPs are consistently attacking internet-connected systems.
2400000.recommendation: Block the source IP. Check for any successful connections from this IP to internal services.

2210000.description: Excessive TCP retransmissions were detected, which may indicate network congestion, packet loss, or a SYN flood attack.
2210000.risk_context: While retransmissions can indicate network issues, excessive retransmissions from a single source may be a denial-of-service attack.
2210000.recommendation: Check network health and bandwidth utilization. If from an external source, consider rate limiting or blocking.

2210020.description: Invalid TLS record types were detected, which may indicate a TLS implementation bug, downgrade attack, or traffic manipulation.
2210020.risk_context: Invalid TLS records can indicate attempts to intercept or manipulate encrypted connections (man-in-the-middle).
2210020.recommendation: Investigate the connection endpoints. Ensure all TLS implementations are up to date. Check for network equipment issues.

2260001.signature: SURICATA HTTP unable to match response to request
2260001.description: HTTP response data could not be matched to a request, which may indicate evasion techniques or protocol violations.
2260001.risk_context: This can indicate HTTP smuggling or desync attacks used to bypass security controls.
2260001.recommendation: Review web server configurations. Check for HTTP smuggling vulnerabilities in reverse proxies and load balancers.

prefix_descriptions.ET POLICY: Network policy violation or notable activity
